awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Connecting Mesoscale Dynamics of Metallic Films on Semiconductors to Nanoscale Phenomena
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract

Electronic devices, such as computers and smartphones, are at the heart of our technological society. Such devices currently are based on semiconductor technology, which involves making electrical contacts between metals and semiconductors. By studying and understanding the details of how metals can be deposited onto semiconductor materials, this project will allow the development of novel methods to grow low dimensional nanostructures, such as extremely thin wires and very thin films. The project connects state-of-the-art experiments to observe the growth properties of the materials with sophisticated theoretical techniques using models consisting of tens to millions of atoms to explore the physics governing the predicted properties of the fabricated nanostructures. Working in conjunction, these methods will facilitate the optimal design and creation of these low dimensional nanostructures. Such structures could be very useful in making future electronic devices, thus maintaining the technological leadership of the U.S. in nanotechnology. Students working on the project will not only gain in-depth physical understanding in the exciting research areas involving metal-semiconductor interfaces but also will engage in outreach activities with local K-12 students and teachers with whom the PIs have on-going interactions, especially through the American Physical Society Physics Teacher Education Coalition (APS PhysTEC). All PIs regularly mentor undergraduate researchers and are actively engaged in recruiting women and underrepresented minority students, particularly through the APS Bridge Program.


Technical Abstract

This project will study the growth mechanisms of several metal on semiconductor systems. The objectives of this project are controlling the growth of low-dimensional (1D and 2D) nanostructures, elucidating the novel and complex collective diffusion behavior which has been observed for these systems, and understanding how quantum behavior can influence epitaxial growth in order to facilitate the optimal design and fabrication of novel materials. A complementary set of experimental and theoretical techniques will be applied to examine systematically the initial growth stages and structural evolution of Ag, Au, and Pb nanostructures on single crystal surfaces of Ge and Si. The atomic ordering and adatom binding sites, as well as sizes and shapes of formed islands, will be determined by scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) and low energy electron microscopy/diffraction (LEEM/LEED) and compared with predictions from density functional theory (DFT)-based simulations. Unusual collective behavior of millions of atoms and quantum size effects (QSE) will be investigated to elucidate details of the mechanisms. Scanning tunneling spectroscopy (STS) and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) will be used to measure local density of states, k-resolved band structure, and quantum well states; these results will be compared with DFT calculations to understand the factors controlling the nanostructure characteristics and to formulate the physical picture about the basic mechanisms and processes for future growth. Bond order potentials (BOP) will be determined for metals bound to semiconductor surfaces and used for self-learning kinetic Monte Carlo (SLKMC) simulations of the growth and movement of islands. These large-scale simulations will improve understanding of the physical origin of the collective motions and suggest additional experimental systems that may display unusual physical phenomena. The use of Si and Ge-based materials would enable rapid development of technological applications for electronic devices.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

First, our ab initio density functional theory (DFT) based calculations of the system energetics and thermodynamics, combined with computer vision modeling, provided rationale for the onset of the experimentally observed growth of Pb nanostructures (obtained by the Chiang group at UC Davis which was funded by the NSF Collaborative Award connected to the current one) once the coverage of Pb exceeded 1.33 monolayers, and the Pb wetting layer on the Ge(111) surface was strained by 2%.  Extensive calculations of the electronic and geometric structure of Ag and Au overlayers on Ge surfaces also provided insights into the nature of the bonding between Ge and Au or Ag atoms, which were subject of experimental observations in the Chiang group. Microscopic physical origins of experimentally observed motion of Au-Ge alloy droplets on Ge(110) were thus obtained. Importantly, the calculated phase diagram of the variety of Ag superstructures on Ge(111) was shown to be in good agreement with experimental observations in the Chiang group, thereby allowing insights based on the local atomic environment and system vibrational dynamics and entropy.

 

Next was the development of an accurate interatomic potential for the Si(100) surface using artificial neural networks and high throughput DFT calculations. Molecular dynamics simulations performed with this interatomic potential revealed metallization of Si(100) starting at 400 K and maximizing at 900 K, in perfect agreement with experimental observations, a feat that had so far been a challenge.  We also developed novel, ML-based techniques for predicting the barriers for diffusion of atomic (transition metal) clusters (containing 2-4 atoms) on the (111) surface of the same transition metal, thereby facilitating efficient computation of thin film growth processes on these surfaces and setting the stage for future multiscale modeling of the growth of metallic nanostructures on semiconductor surfaces.

 

Finally, through collaborative work with colleagues in Spain an efficient methodology was found for multiscale modeling of sub monolayer growth of thin films. In particular for examination of homo- and hetero-epitaxial growth on transition metal (111) surfaces the set of diffusion processes for small metal adatom clusters (containing 2-4 atoms) predicted by the Self Learning Kinetic Monte Carlo method, previously developed by the PI and her coworkers), was combined with a technique that accounts for the multiplicity of a diffusion process, thereby providing an effective activation energy barrier and making the computation very efficient.

 

The broader impact of the proposed work extended from training of students and postdocs, outreach with teachers and students in the Orlando K-12 system, collaborating international interactions, and efforts to enhance diversity and inclusion in the PI’s research group as well as in the UCF Physics Department.

A major landmark has been engagement of students from underrepresented minority (URM)
groups through the Bridge Program from American Physical Society (APS) for which UCF is a funded site with Rahman as the PI. In the duration of this grant the number of UCF Physics URM students increased to 20% of the graduate student body. Consequently, about 20 URM students have been directly mentored by PI Rahman annually. Three URM students have worked in the PI’s research group. One URM student (Andre Child) was heavily engaged in collaborative interactions with the UC Davis team and performed initial DFT based calculations of the electronic structure to provide guidelines to experimental work. He was funded through an AGEP Supplement to the present award and is a coauthor on a publication to be submitted in the near future. Andre is completing the requirements for his PhD degree in Materials Science and Engineering at UCF.   All Bridge Program students are also very involved in outreach activities with students and teachers in the K-12 system and in the community.

Rahman also serves as the PI of the PhysTEC project (funded initially by APS), which aims at increasing the number of physics teachers, through which she and her group members have engaged in outreach activities with local K-12 students and teachers on topics related to this NSF project.

The PI and her senior co-workers presented a large number of invited talks, in which results from projects funded by the present grant were included. Several of the invited talks were presented at international meeting (Pakistan, Germany, Poland, Spain), thereby supporting their broad decimation. Despite COVID 19, her students have presented contributed talks and posters at national and regional meetings.

Five graduate students, four undergraduate students, and two junior scientists were trained through activities related to this grant. Four of the graduate students have already defended their PhD degrees and secured postdoctoral positions in the field.  Two undergraduates are pursuing their PhDs elsewhere, one undergraduate has joined IT workforce, one will graduate soon. Two of the undergraduates are coauthors on publications stemming from the grant – one is the first author. About 50% of Rahman’s group members are females or from URM groups.
